Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: RNA Folding Dynamics by Single Molecule Temperature Jump Kinetics

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award, Prof. David Rueda of Wayne State University and his graduate and undergraduate research students will develop new technology based on the combination of single molecule fluorescence detection with laser induced temperature jump (T-jump) thermal denaturation to study the structural dynamics of RNA molecules. The goal of the research is to understand how functional and structural heterogeneity in single RNA molecules affect the structure-function relationship in biologically important RNAs, as well as to establish a set of physical and chemical rules based upon this knowledge to engineer RNAs with useful applications.

In addition to his research activities, Prof. Rueda will work with high school teachers in the predominantly African-American Detroit School District, through the Wayne State University Department of Education and the Office of Minority Student Initiatives. The bulk of this effort will be focused on developing a summer research program for high school science teachers. This project aims at filling an important gap in the continuous education program of high school science teachers by providing them with first hand experiences in a modern laboratory. Integration of research and education will also be achieved by actively supporting graduate, undergraduate and high school student training in the research laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A method was developed to study the folding energy landscape of kinetically trapped RNAs. Laser-assisted single-molecule spectroscopy (LASR) was introduced as a new technique that extends the capabilities of traditional single-molecule approaches by enabling the study of kinetic traps by heating the buffer around the sample. This method allows information on the magnitude of transition state enthalpies to be obtained. A LASR microscope was built and tested during the funding period. This new technique was tested on kissing hairpin-loop RNAs and also used to examine RNA-folding mechanisms of large, multi-domain RNAs, including the group II intron ribozyme and polypyrimidine tracks in mRNA. The LASR and single-molecule techniques that were developed are significant because they allow the dynamics and conformations of RNA and DNA to be probed, and thus provide insight into folding kinetics and mechanisms, biomolecular interactions, and biological function at a much deeper level than bulk experiments.

 A program for training high school teachers was established. Several biology and chemistry teachers participated in a summer research program, and 16 teachers participated in a laboratory workshop in which they learned how to design and run experiments in RNA biophysics and biochemistry for their students. A program has been established for undergraduate students to participate in outreach activities with local high schools. The outreach activities involving high school teachers, undergraduate students, graduate students, women, and underrepresented minorities have provided unique educational and training opportunities. The students in our university have been given exposure to the broader community, and the high school teachers in the program have gained research experience in cutting-edge chemistry and biology programs.
